Hello everyone and welcome to the
Deconstructor of Fun interview series.
It's been a while. I'm excited to do

looking for something innovative and

of mixes the idea of old school IRL

cool for Gen A and even, you know, some
of the Gen Z folks. This might even be
taking on Pokemon Go. Is it the next

do you remember the game Assassin? So, I
played this back in high school. I was
actually just blown away that kids still
play this game today. So, for those of
you that don't know it, it had a bunch
of different names depending on where
you are in the world, but the idea is
that it's a liveaction elimination game.
Players are secretly assigned targets
that you have to kind of quote kill.
Typically, you use a water gun to like
eliminate someone and then you also have
to avoid being eliminated by whoever's
chasing you. And so, it's kind of last
person standing kind of thing. And it
usually it's a very high school right of

phone, you identify kind of your next

it just really facilitates everything.
So it kind of blends two things
together. So, someone who was in the toy
industry working on things like Nerf,
you know, you think of water guns, you
think of Nerf, I was really intrigued
that this kind of blends everything
together into one thing. So, today we're
going to talk to two of the folks from
Integrated Reality Labs IRL. They have
created a new game called Slap and it's
going to take on Pokémon Go. The cool
thing is that it is going to take what
Pokemon Go does with geoloccation to new
and different places that kind of give
it a shot in a reason for being that
actually makes sense. I think many of
you know on Twig we talk a lot about how
you know sometimes geoloccation hasn't
made sense for some of the other games
because of the IP and the play pattern
not matching up. Well, this is a mix
actually of those two things coming
together. So, my guests today are Lauren
and Ian from IRL. They're going to walk

multiplayer geoloccation gaming. I think
I need to give me a finder fee when I
introduce them to the Nerf team at

Sounds great. Thanks, Jen. I'm Lauren
Stidle. I'm the CEO and one of the

different things, but currently spending
a lot of time preparing for our next
fund raise. Previously, I was the first
hire on the business side of a company
at the intersection of health and

we were building a music therapy mobile
app. Helped scale their EUA and
marketing and comms from preede to
series B. So, I did that for six years.
That was where I cut my teeth. And then
I wanted to start my own company with
Ian, who I've known for many years. And
we've been friends since high school.
We've worked together before, actually.
And now we're running a startup together
and having a lot of fun doing it. Nice.
It's so important to You're almost
married to your business partners. You
spend more time with them. So, it's fun
to hear that you guys have, you know,
kind of a history together. Totally.
Cool. So, Ian, let's hear about you.
Mhm. So I'm the co-founding president of
Integrated Reality Labs and previously
serial entrepreneur expertise in
consumer apps. So especially social
fitness at IRL I'm handling marketing
ops and product. Over the last 10 years
I've started five companies. Two of them
have failed. The one in social fitness
exited. One's a ventureback company in
Philadelphia and now I'm getting to run
integrated reality labs with Lawrence.
All right. So, not a ton of game
industry experience, but a lot of mobile
experience coming into play here. So,
let's get into the actual product and
the platform that you are all building.
So, can you walk me through a little bit

you are blending two different things
together. So, if you're watching on

Yeah. So, our first game is called Slap
and it's basically a modern take on the
classic neighborhood games that we all
grew up playing. So, games like Manhunt,
Capture the Flag, Singer Assassin, um
which is also called Water Wars Some
Places, basically tag and hideand-seek
based games broadly. And since co these
games have been having a renaissance
which started here in the United States
but has really grown to be a large
international phenomenon in part
actually thanks to SLAP. Um so Slap
allows players to digitally tag one
another through their smartphones. You
can play with as few as four friends and
as many as several thousand over pretty
much any sized area. So as small as like
backyard as large as a city. The match
starts with players opening up the game,
inviting their friends who invite their
own friends or other friends into the
lobby. Once everyone joins, all the
players receive a specific target. And
they're also all being targeted by other
players.
Players are using the game map to track
their target. And once you get close to
the person you're pursuing, you
digitally tag them, which triggers a
video of the interaction and at the end
shares that with the other players. The
video also enforces the house rules
which players can decide for themselves
for each match. In the case of games
like Senior Assassin, typically players
eliminate one another with a water
blaster. When there are two people left
or when the time runs out, the game
ends. And as you can see, Slap is really
about bringing back the enjoyment of
connecting with friends, competing in
real life, and spending time with other
people face to face. Wow, that's super
cool. So what I noticed was there was a
lot of video taking and I imagine
obviously with Gen A and Gen Z the first
thing they want to do is share that to
all of their socials. Is there a way
that it instantly kind of blasts every
you know all their social media? How
does that work with the game? So while
the game is being played we share the
video content to the other players who
are taking part in it and then players
are generally taking that and sharing it
to their own socials. We're also
creating geospaccific social media pages
kind of where these games are being
played and we're sharing the content
from the matches to those pages. We're
tagging the nearby schools. Students see
it and then they share it to their own
socials from there. So, there are like a
few different ways that the video
content makes its way onto social media,
but we don't necessarily like push it
out immediately right then and there.
And what's kind of cool about this is it
allows us to basically create this viral
content flywheel and we are seeing all
of this organic growth across the globe
and it's really just coming down to the
core game mechanic is capturing this
video and then it gets shared but that's
also excellent like marketing content.
Yeah. I think when we talked beforehand
and we were looking at it, I'm like, "Oh
my god, you can monetize through
filters, through, you know, different
ways to enhance the video that you're
going to share to make it more fun." And
obviously, you have an instant viral
mechanic to get more people involved and
then to make that video content more
watchable and funny and great. So,
Lauren, what has been the reaction so
far? I think you're out on iOS and
Android in the US, like not that long
though. How long have you been out and
what's been the results? So the company
started in 2022. That was when we
started building our secret sauce tech
that facilitates this. As Ian mentioned,
we have this kind of sensor fusion
approach. That's what allows the digital
tagging. It's super low latency. We
spent most of 2023 and 2024 testing this
out in the context of large scale tag,
the SLAP beta. And then we launched last
month commercially in the US and abroad
on both iOS and Android. And the the
reaction has been really really exciting
has pointed to strong appetite for real
world multiplayer as kind of like a new
gaming category. So we're seeing over
60% of our users are coming in just
organically from you know seeing videos
on Tik Tok and Instagram from outside of
the US. a lot of growth in like the UK,
the UAE, Saudi Arabia, all of these
other marketplaces. And yeah, we're
growing like twice as fast as we had
predicted at this point, which is pretty
exciting. We managed to unlock some
server credits, so that's been helpful
just keeping up with the growth, but
definitely monetization and revenue is
top of mind, kind of leading into this
next stage of growth. What's kind of
interesting too just in terms of like
early user adoption is I think in large
part because of how many social hooks
there are incorporated into the game.
We're seeing that like active users are
opening this 10 times plus per day. So
it's like you know twice as high as like
a or five times as high actually as like
a top performing gaming app and more
like akin to a social network. So
there's like really high level of
engagement and I think it just speaks to
how interested Jenz is in like doing
things socially in person and that uses
video and other UGC elements. I think
you told me the DAU number is pretty
impressive for something that just
launched without a lot of marketing.
Yeah, we're putting like barely anything
toward paid marketing at this point.
It's really just focusing on this like
organic approach and we crossed the
60,000 monthly active user mark. That's
up from like a thousand people in
January. So, it's been growing like over
300% month on month, which is pretty
exciting. Oh, awesome. Okay, so for sure
early days, but what I love hearing is
people who are seeing progress without
the paid media machine that often has to
get into place, which once you do turn
that on could really start to help
things. So, one of the things in
thinking about this was Pokémon Go
Niantic has geoloccation and a lot of
other kind of studios have the same
thing. What is different about your
approach versus what they do? That is a
really good question. Thanks to
navigation and ride share apps,
everyone's pretty much used to seeing
their own location accurately reflected
on a map. But to actually create a real
world multiplayer game, the tricky part
is mapping out the exact proximity of
multiple people relative to each other
in real time, you need to do it fast
enough to actually enable play in real
time. So, when we started this, the best
available mobile tag out there, could
only pinpoint users within about 12 ft
of one another and had refresh times of
up to a few seconds, which is fine for
navigation or like a single player
experience, but was way too slow for
real world multiplayer action. Precision
and real-time responsiveness are really
essential for being fun. So, if you're
playing a game of tag, if your phone
doesn't register interactions
accurately, it's kind of missing the
whole point of the game. So we looked at
previous attempts. People had tried
doing this with GPS alone. It's too
laggy. Others had tried custom hardware,
but it was too expensive for players and
very painful to develop. So we knew our
solution had to use something that
people already had access to. So thanks
to recent developments in Bluetooth and
ultra wideband, these technologies have
become faster and they use battery a lot
less intensively. So this unlocked a
potential solution for us. So we
basically used a sensor fusion approach
where we took the technologies that were
already available like GPS Bluetooth and
fused ultra wideband and Bluetooth so
that we could really understand where
players were in real time using that
peer-to-peer connection between devices.
One last note around like how is this
different from these other location-
based games that we've seen before. a
lot of them have gone, you know, the way
at the Dodo. And I think the really big
difference in addition to what like
everything that Ian's saying like we're
not just using the offtheshelf location
services is the fact that we took as
part of this multiplayer thesis we took
augmented reality and like the screen
overlays out of the equation because we
realized very quickly in looking into
why Niantic and these other companies
that had created these location-based
games when we were looking into why they
hadn't created a multiplayer title we
found that augmented reality quality in
current era mobile just really doesn't
support games in a multiplayer context.
We can go down that rabbit hole from a
technical standpoint, but it kind of
hamstrings you if you're trying to
create like a bonafide multiplayer
experience. Okay. So, your thesis is
like you don't need the AR, you just
focus on geoloccation. It sounds like
Bluetooth plays a big role in this. So,
I imagine part of the rules of the game
is you got to have your Bluetooth on and
that allows you to be able to do much
more multiplayer activity. Is that
right? Yeah. It's like the difference
between a location based game and a
proximity based game. Like ours is based
on proximity. We can see like the 3D
relationships between where people are
in space in a way that like if you're
looking at a map and you have two people
on different floors of a building, it'll
say that they're in the same location,
right? But they might be, you know, very
far apart. And with this technology, we
can get within like with centimeter
level accuracy where individuals are,
whether they're standing next to each
other, whether they're on separate
floors. So that's really what is
critical to unlocking like a fast-paced,
you know, player versus player mechanic.
Oh, interesting. So earlier I should
have been calling it proximity gaming,
not necessarily geoloccation, which is
what we all kind of think of when we
think of this. But that's interesting
that you know maybe you rebrand that a
little bit into the unique direction
that you're going because some of the
comparisons are you know I make that
comparison just to ground people a
little bit in like what the play pattern
is like you're out in the real world and
you're hunting things down. Those things
happen to be other people not
necessarily like hidden objects from the
game is the right way to think about it.
Cool. Just want to make sure I'm groing
it correctly.
Game devs, here at Heroic Labs, we know
that great gameplay is what players
love. But integrating metagame features

All right. So, I got a sense of the tech
and the gameplay on marketing. We talked

significant opportunity. These players,
generally speaking, all already know

They're part of the same communities.
And so, we looked to other hyperlocal
consumer apps that had solved this
problem. So paraatically that looks like
Bumble, Gas and TBH, which both have
scaled through strong local network
effects. And the real trick is tying
gameplay directly into social media. So
for example, every time someone
eliminates another player or what we're

moment on video and we take the content
from the matches and post it to go
specific social media pages. So like
Play Slap UK, Play Slap LA and tag the
nearest schools. Kind of like the bar
stool sports social media empire. Yeah.
The students see themselves in our
videos which they want to share with

out incentive programs to encourage

from the app into social media and we're

a flywheel is something that is

to share, help us identify the optimal
schools and then within those schools
find players that are likely to make
great ambassadors and reach out to them
and work with us through that. That's
been essential to driving our CAC down
low enough to continue growing even

might be. Are you going to add like the

the dating app features because of

it's funny you mentioned that cuz we're

not anticipating going to this, but you

want to lean into in the future. Yes, it

is this an activity you can Anyway, you
could go a lot of different directions.
There's so many like better ways of

direction there. Oh well maybe we should

know the guy who used to be this onto

No, but seriously, I think, you know,

down. Gen A and Gen Z are struggling

know, again, I'm going to market you,
sorry again for this, but one of the

you, while it's a mobile game, it
actually does really facilitate and
foster IRL relationships and promotes
that. I think that's an angle that you
can lean into in the positive like well
you're eliminating or slapping friends

that's what definitely so I think when

this that's where we're going with this
part of the conversation for this being
a platform or an underlying tech that
can be applied to many different things
how are you thinking about expanding
this or using this as a platform where
where are you going with that idea it's
definitely what we have our sights on.
Right now, we're in like heavy execution
mode because we're a startup. So, we're
we're kind of using Slap as the proving
ground for this engine or platform that
we've developed for multiplayer play.
And there's a lot left to do in Slap.
Like Ian mentioned, there's already
these ways kids are using Slap as it's,
you know, the first mode is designed for
senior assassin style play that's
outside of the senior assassin realm.
like with these kind of dating app
angles, we're seeing kids using it as
like a paintball companion app. And so
there's all of these kind of like wrong
ways, quote unquote, that kids are
already starting to use the app and like
requesting other features and ways to
kind of support this. So we're
definitely interested in meeting players
where they want us to uh when it makes
sense and we get like a critical mass of
that input. And ultimately, I think in
doing so, we can like really turn SlapP
into the definitive app for these games
that are rooted in
long-standing like beloved folk
traditions and neighborhood games like
Senior Assassin, but there's tons of
other ones like hideand seek and manhunt
and capture the flag, like you know, the
list goes on and on and we and so
there's a lot left to tease out with
SLAP that we can facilitate in the app
with the engine. But in terms of like
future for integrated reality labs, what
we are really excited about is actually
deputizing our players as we build out
this community to become game creators
in the same way that Roblox has done for
games that are played on screens. We
think because all of these games that
we're already starting to support with
Slap are created by kids and we've
already seen in like the Roblox
community, kids are incredible game
designers when you're giving them like
the toolbox, like the keys to the
kingdom, whatever analogy you want to
use. And we believe we can package up
this technology in a way that is usable
by the players to create and share and
monetize their own real world games.
They can look 100 different ways in
terms of level of complexity, but we're
really excited for that kind of like
future of the platform and really
opening it up to focus on UGC and
leveling up around the UGC we've already
created. Oh, interesting. So, it's a UGC
IRL game that they then kind of program
into the app that allows, you know, the
app to facilitate the game that they
created in the real world. Instead of,
you know, in Roblox, you're in a sense
programming a digital world. This is
you're programming a real world game and
then bringing it into the to the mobile
ecosystem. That's a fun and different
way to think about UGC. I think that's
the perfect synopsis. Awesome. So, we
talked a little earlier about your kind
of tech secret sauce and how you were
thinking about the proximity location as
what was really interesting in your tech
side. Is there any other secret sauce
components that you have as you're
bringing everything together? You know,
you're trying to reach this new
audience. You're trying to do a lot of
different things here. What are some of
the other secret sauce components that
make you unique? I think it really comes
down to understanding who our players
are and what they haven't gotten so far
from gaming. So, they're Gen Z. They
love competitive multiplayer
experiences. They're digital natives, so
they love capturing videos and sharing
them on social media, but they're also
looking to spend more time outside and
to socialize face to face more than they
typically are getting to these days. And
we designed Slap with these three
insights kind of like in the forefront
of our minds. So, we're giving players
the thrill and competition of popular
online games like Fortnite, but with the
built-in social sharing that makes apps
like Tik Tok so sticky. And because we
make every interaction a social moment
where when you digitally tag your
friend, the app captures that moment and
actually uses it as game content, we
make sure that's also always sharable
video content outside of the app. This
formula has not yet been attempted by
previous location-based games. They've
generally speaking relied on AR
geocaching, which are great for like
solitary activities, but don't really
work for multiplayer experiences. Even
Pokémon Go mostly has you playing alone.
With Slap, playing together is the
entire point is already proving out to
be pretty special. Just given one
example, we're seeing that players are
opening the app like on average about 10
times a day. So they're coming back,
they're engaging with it. Retention
rates are pretty high and players seem
to really appreciate the experience.
Okay. So you said retention rates are
high. Have you benchmarked that to
gaming? Is there you definitely have it
in app opens. It sounds like when you're
engaged in the game, you're engaged in
the game. Anything you could share more
around retention rates? Our D1 is right
now is higher than 50%, our D7 is around
20% and our D30 is around 10%. Okay.
Okay. You know, some solid numbers. I
think that's always a good sign. 50% day
one. Awesome. You're going to get that,
right? Because you've got like the viral
nature of a friend asking you to come in
and you want to be a part of the game
and you want to play. So, that's
fantastic. It's making sure they have
that really first good game experience.
game one is amazing and you're doing
something to incentivize them to come
back for game two. That's going to be
super important. As we kind of get to
the end, I imagine you're trying to
think about what's next and how to grow
the company. You said you're a startup.
Lauren, how are you thinking about the
future of IRL? I mean, right now, I
alluded to this in the introduction. We
are gearing up for a new note round. So,
we're still an early stage company, but
we're really excited about the growth
that we're currently seeing. As you
noted, we think that accelerating, you
know, a performance marketing program,
bringing that online now that we've
really cracked the code with the organic
piece of this is worth putting money
into. So, so we're interested in raising
capital to yeah, basically supercharge
growth and also focus on R&D for fully
monetizing the product. So, we have a
bunch of different ideas for
monetization that we're kind of like
testing out and and think are going to
really be able to kind of take this to
the next level. In terms of like the
future for
like far future for IRL in the category,
I think what's interesting and we've
talked a lot about like the differences
between us and Niantic and these other
tech companies. At the end of the day,
we really don't see this as mutually
exclusive from like future smart tech,
but actually as like complimementaryary.
There's been a lot of talk, I think even
on this podcast, about how like the next
generation is like someday we might move
beyond mobile phones and into like an
era of smart glasses or watches or some
combination of all three. That's scary,
I think, to a lot of game developers.
But for us, I think it's actually really
an exciting opportunity. There's a lot
we don't know about what this future is
going to look like, but what we know is
that these devices will all retain the
core sensors, the ultra wideband, the
Bluetooth, all of the things that are

Hello everyone and welcome to the Deconstructor of Fun interview series. It's been a while. I'm excited to do this one. I'm your host Jen Donahoe. I think many of you know I'm always looking for something innovative and different in our space. Today we're going to talk about something that kind of mixes the idea of old school IRL games and mobile in a way that's very cool for Gen A and even, you know, some of the Gen Z folks. This might even be taking on Pokémon GO. Is it the next Pokémon GO killer? Well, we'll see. So, do you remember the game Assassin? So, I played this back in high school. I was actually just blown away that kids still play this game today. So, for those of you that don't know it, it had a bunch of different names depending on where you are in the world, but the idea is that it's a live-action elimination game. Players are secretly assigned targets that you have to kind of quote kill. Typically, you use a water gun to like eliminate someone and then you also have to avoid being eliminated by whoever's chasing you. And so, it's kind of last person standing kind of thing. And it usually it's a very high school right of passage. So now imagine that you can layer on geolocation with the mobile game function. You have social media components. All of this facilitates the game play. So kids can now use the phone, you identify kind of your next target and record all the kills and it it just really facilitates everything. So it kind of blends two things together. So, someone who was in the toy industry working on things like Nerf, you know, you think of water guns, you think of Nerf, I was really intrigued that this kind of blends everything together into one thing. So, today we're going to talk to two of the folks from Integrated Reality Labs (IRL). They have created a new game called SLAP and it's going to take on Pokémon GO. The cool thing is that it is going to take what Pokémon GO does with geolocation to new and different places that kind of give it a shot in a reason for being that actually makes sense. I think many of you know on Twig we talk a lot about how you know sometimes geolocation hasn't made sense for some of the other games because of the IP and the play pattern not matching up. Well, this is a mix actually of those two things coming together. So, my guests today are Lauren and Ian from IRL. They're going to walk us through the blend of IRL social and multiplayer geolocation gaming. I think I need to give me a finder fee when I introduce them to the Nerf team at Hasbro who is going to just absolutely love this and adopt this and pay them a lot of money because it's like the perfect blend. So, let's have them introduce themselves, give a little bit more. Lauren, why don't you go first?
Sounds great. Thanks, Jen. I'm Lauren Steidl. I'm the CEO and one of the co-founders at IRL. I do a lot of different things, but currently spending a lot of time preparing for our next fund raise. Previously, I was the first hire on the business side of a company at the intersection of health and entertainment called Med Rhythms where we were building a music therapy mobile app. Helped scale their EUA and marketing and comms from preede to series B. So, I did that for six years. That was where I cut my teeth. And then I wanted to start my own company with Ian, who I've known for many years. And we've been friends since high school. We've worked together before, actually. And now we're running a startup together and having a lot of fun doing it.
Nice. It's so important to You're almost married to your business partners. You spend more time with them. So, it's fun to hear that you guys have, you know, kind of a history together.
Totally.
Cool. So, Ian, let's hear about you.
Mhm. So I'm the co-founding president of Integrated Reality Labs and previously serial entrepreneur expertise in consumer apps. So especially social fitness at IRL I'm handling marketing ops and product. Over the last 10 years I've started five companies. Two of them have failed. The one in social fitness exited. One's a venture-backed company in Philadelphia and now I'm getting to run Integrated Reality Labs with Lauren.
All right. So, not a ton of game industry experience, but a lot of mobile experience coming into play here. So, let's get into the actual product and the platform that you are all building. So, can you walk me through a little bit more about the gameplay and how that works? We're going to show a video cuz you are blending two different things together. So, if you're watching on YouTube or you're listening or watching on Spotify video, you'll be able to see a little bit more. Obviously, you can go to their website and we'll give you all that in the show notes and at the end.
Yeah. So, our first game is called SLAP and it's basically a modern take on the classic neighborhood games that we all grew up playing. So, games like Manhunt, Capture the Flag, Senior Assassin, um which is also called Water Wars Some Places, basically tag and hide-and-seek based games broadly. And since co these games have been having a renaissance which started here in the United States but has really grown to be a large international phenomenon in part actually thanks to SLAP. Um so SLAP allows players to digitally tag one another through their smartphones. You can play with as few as four friends and as many as several thousand over pretty much any sized area. So as small as like backyard as large as a city. The match starts with players opening up the game, inviting their friends who invite their own friends or other friends into the lobby. Once everyone joins, all the players receive a specific target. And they're also all being targeted by other players.
Players are using the game map to track their target. And once you get close to the person you're pursuing, you digitally tag them, which triggers a video of the interaction and at the end shares that with the other players. The video also enforces the house rules which players can decide for themselves for each match. In the case of games like Senior Assassin, typically players eliminate one another with a water blaster. When there are two people left or when the time runs out, the game ends. And as you can see, SLAP is really about bringing back the enjoyment of connecting with friends, competing in real life, and spending time with other people face to face.
Wow, that's super cool. So what I noticed was there was a lot of video taking and I imagine obviously with Gen A and Gen Z the first thing they want to do is share that to all of their socials. Is there a way that it instantly kind of blasts every you know all their social media? How does that work with the game?
So while the game is being played we share the video content to the other players who are taking part in it and then players are generally taking that and sharing it to their own socials. We're also creating geospaccific social media pages kind of where these games are being played and we're sharing the content from the matches to those pages. We're tagging the nearby schools. Students see it and then they share it to their own socials from there. So, there are like a few different ways that the video content makes its way onto social media, but we don't necessarily like push it out immediately right then and there. And what's kind of cool about this is it allows us to basically create this viral content flywheel and we are seeing all of this organic growth across the globe and it's really just coming down to the core game mechanic is capturing this video and then it gets shared but that's also excellent like marketing content.
Yeah. I think when we talked beforehand and we were looking at it, I'm like, "Oh my god, you can monetize through filters, through, you know, different ways to enhance the video that you're going to share to make it more fun." And obviously, you have an instant viral mechanic to get more people involved and then to make that video content more watchable and funny and great. So, Lauren, what has been the reaction so far? I think you're out on iOS and Android in the US, like not that long though. How long have you been out and what's been the results?
So the company started in 2022. That was when we started building our secret sauce tech that facilitates this. As Ian mentioned, we have this kind of sensor fusion approach. That's what allows the digital tagging. It's super low latency. We spent most of 2023 and 2024 testing this out in the context of large scale tag, the SLAP beta. And then we launched last month commercially in the US and abroad on both iOS and Android. And the the reaction has been really really exciting has pointed to strong appetite for real world multiplayer as kind of like a new gaming category. So we're seeing over 60% of our users are coming in just organically from you know seeing videos on TikTok and Instagram from outside of the US. a lot of growth in like the UK, the UAE, Saudi Arabia, all of these other marketplaces. And yeah, we're growing like twice as fast as we had predicted at this point, which is pretty exciting. We managed to unlock some server credits, so that's been helpful just keeping up with the growth, but definitely monetization and revenue is top of mind, kind of leading into this next stage of growth. What's kind of interesting too just in terms of like early user adoption is I think in large part because of how many social hooks there are incorporated into the game. We're seeing that like active users are opening this 10 times plus per day. So it's like you know twice as high as like a or five times as high actually as like a top performing gaming app and more like akin to a social network. So there's like really high level of engagement and I think it just speaks to how interested Jenz is in like doing things socially in person and that uses video and other UGC elements.
I think you told me the DAU number is pretty impressive for something that just launched without a lot of marketing.
Yeah, we're putting like barely anything toward paid marketing at this point. It's really just focusing on this like organic approach and we crossed the 60,000 monthly active user mark. That's up from like a thousand people in January. So, it's been growing like over 300% month on month, which is pretty exciting.
Oh, awesome. Okay, so for sure early days, but what I love hearing is people who are seeing progress without the paid media machine that often has to get into place, which once you do turn that on could really start to help things. So, one of the things in thinking about this was Pokémon GO Niantic has geolocation and a lot of other kind of studios have the same thing. What is different about your approach versus what they do?
That is a really good question. Thanks to navigation and ride share apps, everyone's pretty much used to seeing their own location accurately reflected on a map. But to actually create a real world multiplayer game, the tricky part is mapping out the exact proximity of multiple people relative to each other in real time, you need to do it fast enough to actually enable play in real time. So, when we started this, the best available mobile tag out there, could only pinpoint users within about 12 ft of one another and had refresh times of up to a few seconds, which is fine for navigation or like a single player experience, but was way too slow for real world multiplayer action. Precision and real-time responsiveness are really essential for being fun. So, if you're playing a game of tag, if your phone doesn't register interactions accurately, it's kind of missing the whole point of the game. So we looked at previous attempts. People had tried doing this with GPS alone. It's too laggy. Others had tried custom hardware, but it was too expensive for players and very painful to develop. So we knew our solution had to use something that people already had access to. So thanks to recent developments in Bluetooth and ultra wideband, these technologies have become faster and they use battery a lot less intensively. So this unlocked a potential solution for us. So we basically used a sensor fusion approach where we took the technologies that were already available like GPS Bluetooth and fused ultra wideband and Bluetooth so that we could really understand where players were in real time using that peer-to-peer connection between devices. One last note around like how is this different from these other location-based games that we've seen before. a lot of them have gone, you know, the way at the Dodo. And I think the really big difference in addition to what like everything that Ian's saying like we're not just using the offtheshelf location services is the fact that we took as part of this multiplayer thesis we took augmented reality and like the screen overlays out of the equation because we realized very quickly in looking into why Niantic and these other companies that had created these location-based games when we were looking into why they hadn't created a multiplayer title we found that augmented reality quality in current era mobile just really doesn't support games in a multiplayer context. We can go down that rabbit hole from a technical standpoint, but it kind of hamstrings you if you're trying to create like a bonafide multiplayer experience.
Okay. So, your thesis is like you don't need the AR, you just focus on geolocation. It


Sounds like Bluetooth plays a big role in this. So, I imagine part of the rules of the game is you got to have your Bluetooth on and that allows you to be able to do much more multiplayer activity. Is that right? Yeah. It's like the difference between a location-based game and a proximity-based game. Like ours is based on proximity. We can see like the 3D relationships between where people are in space in a way that like if you're looking at a map and you have two people on different floors of a building, it'll say that they're in the same location, right? But they might be, you know, very far apart. And with this technology, we can get within like with centimeter level accuracy where individuals are, whether they're standing next to each other, whether they're on separate floors. So that's really what is critical to unlocking like a fast-paced, you know, player versus player mechanic.

Oh, interesting. So earlier I should have been calling it proximity gaming, not necessarily geolocation, which is what we all kind of think of when we think of this. But that's interesting that you know maybe you rebrand that a little bit into the unique direction that you're going because some of the comparisons are you know I make that comparison just to ground people a little bit in like what the play pattern is like you're out in the real world and you're hunting things down. Those things happen to be other people not necessarily like hidden objects from the game is the right way to think about it. Cool. Just want to make sure I'm groing it correctly.

All right. So, I got a sense of the tech and the gameplay on marketing. We talked a little bit about more of the organic approach. Can you tell me you a little bit more about how you're thinking about this, especially because it's such a hard-to-reach audience with Jen Donahoe and Jenz? Yeah, it is definitely a unique challenge, but it's also very significant opportunity. These players, generally speaking, all already know each other or at least have weak ties. They're part of the same communities. And so, we looked to other hyperlocal consumer apps that had solved this problem. So paraatically that looks like Bumble, Gas and TBH, which both have scaled through strong local network effects. And the real trick is tying gameplay directly into Social Media. So for example, every time someone eliminates another player or what we're calling slaps, the app captures that moment on video and we take the content from the matches and post it to go specific Social Media pages. So like Play SLAP UK, Play SLAP LA and tag the nearest schools. Kind of like the bar stool sports Social Media empire. Yeah. The students see themselves in our videos which they want to share with their friends. They share to their own socials. We've not yet started rolling out incentive programs to encourage players to share their flaps directly from the app into Social Media and we're already seeing vow growth due to the content sharing. So we know that this as a flywheel is something that is fundamentally working and that we want to continue investing into. We've also developed some what we're calling growth technologies. So using AI and other tools to help us select the best videos to share, help us identify the optimal schools and then within those schools find players that are likely to make great ambassadors and reach out to them and work with us through that. That's been essential to driving our CAC down low enough to continue growing even though our marketing budget has been fractional compared to what otherwise might be.

Are you going to add like the Tinder feature where you like swipe left and swipe? Yes, it is a meetup. Meetup's another thing and dating is another thing. It's like, huh, is this an activity you can Anyway, you could go a lot of different directions. No, but seriously, I think, you know, dating is struggling and, you know, I listen to a lot of podcasts that talk about how the friendships are going down. Gen Z and Gen A are struggling with loneliness because they're not meeting people IRL. And so, one of, you know, again, I'm going to market you, sorry again for this, but one of the benefits that you could offer is that you, while it's a mobile game, it actually does really facilitate and foster IRL relationships and promotes that. I think that's an angle that you can lean into in the positive like well you're eliminating or slapping friends but still play is fun right like it that's what definitely so I think when we talked too you had aspirations of this that's where we're going with this part of the conversation for this being a platform or an underlying tech that can be applied to many different things how are you thinking about expanding this or using this as a platform where where are you going with that idea it's definitely what we have our sights on. Right now, we're in like heavy execution mode because we're a startup. So, we're we're kind of using SLAP as the proving ground for this engine or platform that we've developed for multiplayer play. And there's a lot left to do in SLAP. Like Ian mentioned, there's already these ways kids are using SLAP as it's, you know, the first mode is designed for senior assassin style play that's outside of the senior assassin realm. like with these kind of dating app angles, we're seeing kids using it as like a paintball companion app. And so there's all of these kind of like wrong ways, quote unquote, that kids are already starting to use the app and like requesting other features and ways to kind of support this. So we're definitely interested in meeting players where they want us to uh when it makes sense and we get like a critical mass of that input. And ultimately, I think in doing so, we can like really turn SLAPgame into the definitive app for these games that are rooted in long-standing like beloved folk traditions and neighborhood games like Senior Assassin, but there's tons of other ones like hideand seek and manhunt and capture the flag, like you know, the list goes on and on and we and so there's a lot left to tease out with SLAPgame that we can facilitate in the app with the engine. But in terms of like future for Integrated Reality Labs, what we are really excited about is actually deputizing our players as we build out this community to become game creators in the same way that Roblox has done for games that are played on screens. We think because all of these games that we're already starting to support with SLAPgame are created by kids and we've already seen in like the Roblox community, kids are incredible game designers when you're giving them like the toolbox, like the keys to the kingdom, whatever analogy you want to use. And we believe we can package up this technology in a way that is usable by the players to create and share and monetize their own real world games. They can look 100 different ways in terms of level of complexity, but we're really excited for that kind of like future of the platform and really opening it up to focus on UGC and leveling up around the UGC we've already created.

Oh, interesting. So, it's a UGC IRL game that they then kind of program into the app that allows, you know, the app to facilitate the game that they created in the real world. Instead of, you know, in Roblox, you're in a sense programming a digital world. This is you're programming a real world game and then bringing it into the to the mobile ecosystem. That's a fun and different way to think about UGC. I think that's the perfect synopsis. Awesome. So, we talked a little earlier about your kind of tech secret sauce and how you were thinking about the proximity location as what was really interesting in your tech side. Is there any other secret sauce components that you have as you're bringing everything together? You know, you're trying to reach this new audience. You're trying to do a lot of different things here. What are some of the other secret sauce components that make you unique? I think it really comes down to understanding who our players are and what they haven't gotten so far from gaming. So, they're Gen Z. They love competitive multiplayer experiences. They're digital natives, so they love capturing videos and sharing them on Social Media, but they're also looking to spend more time outside and to socialize face to face more than they typically are getting to these days. And we designed SLAPgame with these three insights kind of like in the forefront of our minds. So, we're giving players the thrill and competition of popular online games like Fortnite, but with the built-in social sharing that makes apps like TikTok so sticky. And because we make every interaction a social moment where when you digitally tag your friend, the app captures that moment and actually uses it as game content, we make sure that's also always sharable video content outside of the app. This formula has not yet been attempted by previous location-based games. They've generally speaking relied on AR geocaching, which are great for like solitary activities, but don't really work for multiplayer experiences. Even Pokémon GO mostly has you playing alone. With SLAPgame, playing together is the entire point is already proving out to be pretty special. Just given one example, we're seeing that players are opening the app like on average about 10 times a day. So they're coming back, they're engaging with it. Retention rates are pretty high and players seem to really appreciate the experience.

Okay. So you said retention rates are high. Have you benchmarked that to gaming? Is there you definitely have it in app opens. It sounds like when you're engaged in the game, you're engaged in the game. Anything you could share more around retention rates? Our D1 is right now is higher than 50%, our D7 is around 20% and our D30 is around 10%. Okay. Okay. You know, some solid numbers. I think that's always a good sign. 50% day one. Awesome. You're going to get that, right? Because you've got like the viral nature of a friend asking you to come in and you want to be a part of the game and you want to play. So, that's fantastic. It's making sure they have that really first good game experience. game one is amazing and you're doing something to incentivize them to come back for game two. That's going to be super important. As we kind of get to the end, I imagine you're trying to think about what's next and how to grow the company. Lauren, how are you thinking about the future of IRL? I mean, right now, I alluded to this in the introduction. We are gearing up for a new note round. So, we're still an early stage company, but we're really excited about the growth that we're currently seeing. As you noted, we think that accelerating, you know, a performance marketing program, bringing that online now that we've really cracked the code with the organic piece of this is worth putting money into.
